Mod.MiscDesc: Upgrades the ability of all opposed Stealth checks made against sensor and scanner operators once.

ItemAttachment.Name: Stealth Field Generator
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Stealth Field Generator[h3] Produced by a number of stealth technology companies, stealth field generators are the final word in personal active stealth technology. They use a combination of optical camouflage, low-output cloaking technology, active electromagnetic dampers, electronic acoustic bafflers, and thermal shielding to make a user virtually invisible to both the naked eye and to most scanners. These systems are not perfect, however. Users still need to know how to move stealthily and how to use cover and shadows to their advantage. Users also cannot move faster than a walk, or the stealth field will break down. This attachment can be applied to any armor. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Fabritech XO-A "Vanish l" Personal Stealth Generator, Kerner Corp. "Defel" Cloaking Belt.

Mod.MiscDesc: Upgrades the difficulty of all opposed Perception checks to spot the wearer once.
Add [SE] to opposed Perception checks to notice the wearer

ItemAttachment.Name: Concealed Climbing Cord
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Concealed Climbing Cord[h3] This mod consists of a small retracting spool wrapped with twenty-five meters of thin, high tensile strength climbing line, connected to a small, spring-loaded grappling hook. Typically built into a belt, sash, or other load-bearing strap, a concealed climbing cord can get an agent into and out of a lot of trouble in a variety of mission settings. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Grants the user a length of climbing cord with grappling hook. This counts as having the Right Tool for the Job for climbing and repelling.

ItemAttachment.Name: Dart Gun
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Dart Gun[h3] This is a simple device that uses springs or compressed air to fire a tiny alloy dart. While they do very little damage, these darts can be coated with a number of exotic substances, from sedatives to extremely lethal toxins. Dart guns are often concealed in comlinks, glow rods, cigarras, and other cylindrical items, but they can be used anywhere for both offensive and defensive purposes. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Enable the item to fire a single dart with the following profile: (Ranged [Light]: Damage 2; Critical 5; Range [Short]; Limited Ammo 1, Pierce 1).

ItemAttachment.Name: Hidden Compartment
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Hidden Compartment[h3] These are typically very small, easily concealed compartments hidden in places such as the hollowed-out handle of a blaster pistol or the heel of a shoe. Due to size constraints, they can typically only hold items with an encumbrance of 0, such as mem-stiks and credit chips. Compartments that can hold items with an encumbrance of 1 or 2 can be built into larger items, such as a false bottom in a document case. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Adds a small hidden compartment to a personal item. Finding the compartment requires a thorough once-over and a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Perception check[b].
Upgrade difficulty of Perception check required to discover compartment once

ItemAttachment.Name: Holo Converter
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Holo Converter[h3] Holo converters are common holo scrambling devices that allow users to alter a holoprojector's outgoing signal. Using powerful alteration technologies, holo converters allow users to change their species, age, gender, and any other identifying features on camera to hide their identity. This can be used with any holographic recording/projecting device, and the converter can store four different alter egos in its database. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Allows a user to create disguises within holographic recording/projecting systems
Add one additional alter ego to the database

ItemAttachment.Name: Comlink Bug
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Comlink Bug[h3] Comlink bugs are tiny listening devices implanted into an otherwise normal comlink. When active, they allow an operator to listen in on whatever is being broadcast over a specific comlink. These devices detect both incoming and outgoing signals and can record entire conversations. As they are active listening devices, comlink bugs can be detected with proper equipment, such as a surveillance scanner. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Broadcasts all incoming and outgoing signals from a comlink to a remote listener at medium range.

ItemAttachment.Name: Subminiature Holocam
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Subminiature Holocam[h3] Subminiature holocams are small holorecorders equipped with a medium-sized fixed focal length lens. Able to record still images and video in numerous formats, they are often hidden in datapads, eyeglasses, goggles, or jewelry. Due to their size and the nature of the attached lens, they have relatively limited capabilities. The on-board storage can store only a handful of still images or a few minutes of video, and the images are all low-resolution. Unless the subminiature holocam is specifically built for the task, it can only reliably record up to a range of three meters. In addition, miniature holocams rarely, if ever, have networking capabilities; images and video footage must be removed manually by connecting the device to a datapad or computer. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Xonim Holotech VEF22 SubMiniature Holocam.

Mod.MiscDesc: Allows a user to take still images and record holos unobtrusively

ItemAttachment.Name: Retractable Garrote
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Retractable Garrote[h3] This simple mod adds a garrote to any suitable item, typically a briefcase, comlink, bracelet, or shoe, but it can even be used on a stimpack or fusion lantern. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Equips the item with a retractable garrote.

ItemAttachment.Name: Self-Destruct System
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Self-Destruct System[h3] Self-destruct systems are found on many pieces of espionage gear, especially bags, attaché cases, and diplomatic pouches. They use small, low-yield, shaped-charge explosives to destroy the item in case of theft, emergency, or improper usage. For example, an attaché case could be equipped with a self-destruct system that activates when an incorrect lock combination is entered. The explosions are usually very contained, but can be modified to deal damage to others nearby when the device detonates. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Equips the item with a single use explosive self-destruct system that inflicts 5 damage to all characters within engaged range
Increase damage by 2
Increase range to short

ItemAttachment.Name: Cloaking Device
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Cloaking Device[h3] Cloaking devices are exceedingly rare and typically only fitted to starships employed in gathering intelligence assignments. Fueled with either hibridium or stygium, these power-hungry systems render a ship completely invisible. Cloaking devices are illegal to own for non-military use, a fact that is largely lost on those few criminals, smugglers, and espionage freelancers who are wealthy enough to afford them. This attachment can be applied to any starship of silhouette 3 or larger. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Sienar Fleet Systems Mk Ill Stygium Cloaking Device, Kerner Corp Multi-Phase Hibridium Stealth System.

Mod.MiscDesc: Provides a starship with a cloaking device which can be activated or deactivated by spending a maneuver. A character must make a [B]Daunting ([DI][DI][DI]) Perception[b] or [B]Vigilance check[b] to spot a cloaked ship. Ships with an active cloaking device have their speed reduced by half (rounded up) and can not use active sensors, comms, or weapons.

ItemAttachment.Name: Holographic Shell
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Holographic Shell[h3] Holographic shells use a combination of optical camouflage and high-resolution holography to create a disguised exterior for a ship or vehicle. A disguise must be programmed into the system's memory in advance, and the memory can hold only one disguise. Once active, a disguise cannot be changed on the fly. Holographic disguises are only effective at distances of several meters or more, however; touching or closely investigating the disguise ruins the illusion. This attachment can be applied to any starship or vehicle. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Provides a ship or vehicle with a holographic disguise. A [B]Daunting ([DI][DI][DI][DI]) Perception check[b] is required to see through the disguise at a distance. Physical examination immediately detects the disguise.
Add one additional disguise to the database

ItemAttachment.Name: Hush Kit
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Hush Kit[h3] Hush kits were originally designed to muffle the sound of ion and rocket engines around urban spaceports. Installed on a starship's engines, these devices dramatically reduces the sound engines produce. Shortly after their introduction, though, it became apparent that hush kits also make it easier to sneak ships and speeders into and out of places they don't belong. They have since become common among criminals, scouts, and intelligence agents. This attachment can be applied to any starship or vehicle. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Incom 44L2 "Whisperer" Hush Kit, SoroSuub "Slipstream" Stage Ill Hush Kit.

Mod.MiscDesc: Adds [SE][SE] to all checks to detect this ship audibly while it is in atmosphere.

ItemAttachment.Name: Mobile Listening Post
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Mobile Listening Post[h3] Mobile listening posts are a common modification to vehicles used by law enforcement and intelligence agencies. They pack everything an agent or small group of agents needs for a long stakeout. Models commonly include comms interceptors, various powerful sensors and scanners, and of course a small but well stocked caf maker. This attachment can be applied to any enclosed vehicle of silhouette 5 or larger. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Increases a vehicle's passive and active sensors by one band. Provides extra audio, video, and holographic capabilities.

ItemAttachment.Name: Retractable Weapon System
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Retractable Weapon System[h3] A staple of spies and infiltrators, this simple mechanical apparatus deploys and retracts a weapon from a hidden spot aboard a ship or vehicle. The does not include the weapon, just the retractable mechanism and the work done to make a concealed space for the weapon beneath duralloy or other hull plates. This attachment can be applied to any starship or vehicle. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Provides a vehicle with a hidden compartment and a device for deploying a weapon. Deploying or retracting a weapon requires a maneuver. Discovering a retractable weapon system requires a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Perception check[b] and a thorough search of the ship or vehicle in question. The GM has final say if a weapon is suitable for the retraction system based on the size of the ship or vehicle.

ItemAttachment.Name: Sensor Shunt
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Sensor Shunt[h3] Sensor shunts are passive stealth systems fitted to ships or vehicles to hide energy signatures. Unlike a scrambler, which draws attention to itself even as it fools sensors, shunts are quiet and unobtrusive. Ships or vehicles with these upgrades are nearly invisible to passive sensors and are difficult to detect with even active scanners. This attachment can be applied to any starship or vehicle. [P][B]Models Include:[b] Various models.

Mod.MiscDesc: Increase the difficulty of checks to detect this vessel using passive sensors by two, and the difficulty of checks to detect this vessel using active sensors by one, while it is traveling at speed 3 or lower.

ItemAttachment.Name: Concealment Alteration (Weapon)
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Concealment Alteration (Weapon)[h3] Holdout blasters and vibroknives are easy enough to hide, but when characters wish to pack a bit more of a punch, they need a more powerful (and usually larger) weapon. The simplest way to make a more obvious weapon or other item easier to conceal is to remove unnecessary parts or minimize its size. This is called a concealment alteration. Concealment alterations can include cutting weapon barrels, removing panels, and any other small physical changes that do not prohibit the item's primary function. [P]PCs wishing to make a concealment alteration need to make an [B]Average ([DI][DI]) Skulduggery check[b] and spend one hour per point of the item's encumbrance (with a minimum duration of one hour) in applying the changes. A successful check reduces the item's encumbrance by 1 (to a minimum of 1) and adds [SE] to any Perception checks to notice or search for the item; [TR] can be spent to make this [SE][SE] instead. Items with an encumbrance of 3 or higher are more difficult to modify, however, and so the difficulty to perform a concealment alteration increases by one for each point of encumbrance over 2. This means that making a concealment alteration to a typical ion blaster (encumbrance 3) would require a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Skulduggery check[b], while doing so to a standard disruptor rifle (encumbrance 5) would require a [B]Formidable ([DI][DI][DI]) Skulduggery check[b]. Items with an encumbrance of 6 or higher cannot receive a concealment alteration. [P]A character can only attempt a concealment alteration once on a given item, and doing so permanently reduces the item's available hard points by 1. Items that have no hard points may still be altered in this fashion.

Mod.MiscDesc: PCs wishing to make a concealment alteration need to make an [B]Average ([DI][DI]) Skulduggery check[b] and spend one hour per point of the item's encumbrance (with a minimum duration of one hour) in applying the changes. Items with an encumbrance of 3 or higher are more difficult to modify, however, and so the difficulty to perform a concealment alteration increases by one for each point of encumbrance over 2. Items with an encumbrance of 6 or higher cannot receive a concealment alteration.

ItemAttachment.Name: Component Alteration (Weapon)
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Component Alteration (Weapon)[h3] A more drastic, but more effective, option is to alter a weapon or other device so that it can be broken down into several smaller parts that can be reassembled later. This method is typically used when a Rebel needs to get a larger item into a secure location or to avoid scanning devices that are likely to detect standard weapons regardless of any concealment alterations. This is called a component alteration. [P]Characters wishing to break a weapon or other item down into several parts in this fashion need to spend time dismantling the device into smaller components. This requires a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Mechanics check[b] and takes a number of hours equal to the item's encumbrance, or a minimum of one hour. If the check is successful, the device is broken down into a number of components equal to its encumbrance plus 1. So, a blaster pistol is broken down into two components, while a blaster rifle is broken down into five. [P]Note that this differs from the more advanced componentization weapon attachment, which requires no check for use once it is installed and is designed to allow the user to openly carry a weapon, rather than consisting of a simple mechanical disassembly. Characters can try, though, to use component alteration to physically disguise these individual parts to look like code cylinders, comlinks, fusion lanterns, and other mundane objects. While this allows a part to take on the rough appearance of the desired object, it does not gain the functionality of that object. This is generally a taxing and tricky process, and so upgrades the difficulty of the Mechanics check once or more as per the GM's discretion. [P]Each [SU] or [TR] on the initial Mechanics check lets a character carrying the components from a component alteration add [BO] to [B]opposed Stealth vs. Perception checks[b] when an observer attempts to notice the true nature of the disassembled device. If the component alteration was designed to make the items appear mundane, he gains [BO][BO] instead. [P]Assembling a weapon or other item with a component alteration requires two maneuvers or two minutes of narrative time per component, and the character must make an [B]Average ([DI][DI]) Mechanics check[b]. All components must be present to make the check. Failure means the components are damaged and the device requires a major repair to be properly reassembled again and returned to function. [P]Component alterations have a strong impact on a item's reliability, as most weapons or other complex devices simply aren't meant to be broken down into smaller pieces and reassembled. The GM may spend [TH][TH][TH] as [DE] when a character makes a skill check while using an item with this alteration. Items that have no hard points may still be altered in this fashion.

ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Component Alteration (Gear)[h3] A more drastic, but more effective, option is to alter a weapon or other device so that it can be broken down into several smaller parts that can be reassembled later. This method is typically used when a Rebel needs to get a larger item into a secure location or to avoid scanning devices that are likely to detect standard weapons regardless of any concealment alterations. This is called a component alteration. [P]Characters wishing to break a weapon or other item down into several parts in this fashion need to spend time dismantling the device into smaller components. This requires a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Mechanics check[b] and takes a number of hours equal to the item's encumbrance, or a minimum of one hour. If the check is successful, the device is broken down into a number of components equal to its encumbrance plus 1. ItemAttachment.Name: Hidden Compartments in Armor
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Hidden Compartments in Armor[h3] Usually formed from rigid plates or packed with protective padding, most types of armor rarely facilitate the stowing of small objects. However, with some careful work, a character can add hidden pouches, concealed holsters, and unseen sheaths. [P]A character typically shaves down or hollows out a section of armor plating, or thins out protective mesh and padding, to make space for the hidden compartment. To make this change, he must spend a number of hours equal to the armor's encumbrance, pay a number of credits equal to 5% of the armor's price, and make a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Mechanics check[b]. Each [SU] or [TR] provides one encumbrance point's worth of hidden space in the armor. The armor cannot gain more encumbrance points for hiding objects than the suit's own encumbrance value, and items concealed in this way do not count towards the user's encumbrance threshold. Add [SE][SE] to all Perception checks made to notice items hidden in this manner. [P]No matter how many [SU] are rolled, though, a suit of armor cannot conceal any single item with an encumbrance value greater than 2. This means that if a character rolls [SU][SU][SU] and thus has space for items totaling 3 encumbrance, the character could conceal a heavy blaster pistol (encumbrance 2) and a vibroknife (encumbrance 1), but not a blaster carbine (encumbrance 3). This is because while it is possible to hollow out a compartment in a chest plate and perhaps a second in a boot, there is no single location on a suit of armor large enough to accommodate a particularly large or unwieldy item. [P]Each point of encumbrance value for concealed space gained in this fashion reduces the armor's hard points by one, to a minimum of 0. Any armor with no hard points, such as padded armor or heavy clothing, can still have enough concealed space for an item with an encumbrance value of 1. [P]For every two encumbrance points' worth of concealed space created, an armor's soak is reduced by one. However, each net [AD] on the initial Mechanics check to modify the armor cancels out one point of soak reduction.

ItemAttachment.Name: Whipcord Thrower
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Whipcord Thrower[h3] A whipcord thrower quickly deploys a length of high-tensile strength cable, firing it over a distance in order to secure a target. Its convenient armor mounting allows the user to act quickly, whether to arrest their own freefall, secure a loose object, or entangle a surprised opponent.

Mod.MiscDesc: Whipcord throwers can be used as climbing gear to assist the wearer in climbing a steep vertical surface, reducing the difficulty to climb by one. they may support a weight up to 200 kilograms. Further, the thrower may be used as a weapon with the following profile: {Melee, Damage +1, Critical 5; Range [Short]; Ensnare 2)

ItemAttachment.Name: Portable Plasma Shield
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Portable Plasma Shield[h3] Armor and weapon designs oppose one another in a cycle of endless escalation. Not surprisingly, many warriors seek out means to enhance their defenses in hopes that it will leave them free to make additional attacks. A small defensive shield can provide a substantial upgrade. energy Shields take this a step further, offering a near-inpenetrable defense while requiring much less weight and bulk than a more traditional shield.

ItemAttachment.Name: Bio-Support Dispenser
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Bio-Support Dispenser[h3] Sophisticated medical technology integrated into armor can enhance the effects of in-combat treatments through carefully regulated and distributed dosages. This system applies medication automatically as the wearer's vitals begin to suffer, and It Includes an internal bacta reservoir for sealing the most grievous injuries. This attachment may only be installed on a fully enclosed suit of armor, such as laminate, clone trooper, or heavy battle armor

Mod.MiscDesc: When the wearer heals strain at the end of an encounter, they also heal I wound if they suffered any wounds during the encounter. In addition, the first time in an encounter that the character's current wounds exceed half their wound threshold, the armor automatically applies a stimpack to the character

ItemAttachment.Name: Spoofing Scanners
ItemAttachment.Description: [H3]Spoofing Scanners[h3] Some physical alterations, no matter how extensive, can't fool the piercing eyes of scanners and electronic detection devices. However, clever Rebels aren't without hope. By reducing the energy output of a weapon or by installing jury-rigged scramblers to shield a device from sensory devices, a character can potentially allow the item to evade detection. [P]Characters attempting such an alteration must make a [B]Hard ([DI][DI][DI]) Mechanics check[b]. This adds [SE] to Perception checks that operators using a scanning device make to detect the item. They may spend [TR] from the Mechanics check to have the difficulty of such detection checks upgraded once. [P]Unfortunately, the reduction of a weapon's energy output does diminish its effectiveness. Each net [SU] from the check for reducing a weapon's energy output also reduces its damage by one, to a minimum of 1. Characters may spend [TR] from the Mechanics check to halve this reduction in damage, rounding up. [P]Only weapons that use energy-based attacks or other advanced devices can have their energy output reduced or signature concealed. This means that slugthrowers and traditional explosive devices cannot be modified in this fashion. In addition, items that require extensive power (such as repeating blasters) cannot have their energy signature reduced. Note that this differs from the scanner-proof hardware weapon attachment, which requires no check for use once it is installed and is more a customization of the weapon than a mechanical alteration.
